Award.AwardTitle: The NextBio Project: A Student Collaboratory for Biology Cyberlearning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Concord Consortium, the Maine Mathematics and Science Alliance, the Jackson Laboratory and several other partners are determining the feasibility of engaging students in experimentally-oriented bioinformatics and DNA science cyberlearning modules by developing and studying 17 computer-based instructional modules that can be used in high school biology courses. Students are working in virtual laboratories to conduct genetics research on populations of mythical dragons by manipulating models and simulations based on well-known genetic disorders. The modules require students to work collaboratively and publish their findings for peer review by the NextBio user community. The NextBio Project is also providing teachers with professional development in cutting-edge science content and cyberlearning environments. The project is answering important research questions pertaining to the impact of cyber-based learning materials on student learning with comparisons to traditional materials. The project will further educators' understanding of how biology teachers integrate cyberlearning into their classrooms and measure the effectiveness of virtual laboratories in teaching science to high school biology students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The nature of science is to discover the underlying causes of phenomena by doing experiments. The immersive nature of digital games offers an exciting alternative for exploring science by engaging students more fully in authentic problems that can be solved via virtual experimentation. With a five-year grant from the National Science Foundation, the Concord Consortium designed and developed Geniverse (http://concord.org/projects/geniverse), an online educational game for learning genetics at the high school and middle school levels.

Geniverse provides teachers with the resources and materials they need to bring their students the richness and depth of scientific discovery. Geniverse students unlock the secrets of heredity by doing virtual experiments using a genetics simulation embedded in the game. In contrast, real genetics experiments are very difficult to do in schools. Teachers must have the materials and space to maintain or grow stocks of model organisms (examples include fruit flies and specialized fast-growing plants). Expensive resources, including time, are too often wasted in an attempt to do genetics in classrooms. To circumvent these traditional obstacles of time and space and yet provide a means for experimentation that closely mimics laboratory genetics, we programmed the genetics of the real world into the virtual environment of Geniverse. Students can conduct breeding experiments instantaneously and can easily repeat and verify their results.

To engage students, Geniverse uses an imaginary species—the dragon—but programs it with real-world genetics taken from species such as mouse and lizard. Through a series of 32 challenges across four levels of difficulty, students work their way up through a Dragon Genetics Guild. In every challenge, there are multiple pathways for students to achieve the objective; all involve experimenting with genes, breeding strategies, and different patterns of inheritance (for example, dominance or recessiveness). Students can only discover how a trait is inherited by breeding pairs of parents to reveal the underlying genetic mechanisms. They are awarded 1, 2, or 3 stars based on the degree of skill (efficiency) they show in meeting the challenge. The greater the understanding of the pattern of inheritance, the more efficiently the student will be able to produce the target, revealing the skill level of the student. Students frequently repeat challenges in order to improve their star rating as they track their own progress through the game.

In some challenges students must go farther, and explain their discoveries of a genetic mechanism in writing. This takes the form of a scientific argument: students submit a claim (for example, "Copper coloring is dominant to lava coloring") and support their claim with evidence (data) from their experiments, and connect the evidence and the claim with reasoning.

To support teachers in their use of this innovative approach, we created a companion website called Geniversity (http://geniverse.concord.org/geniversity) that includes videos for getting started, lesson plans, teacher guides, a discussion forum, and student handouts. Since its inception in September of 2013, the various pages of the Geniversity teacher resource website have been accessed close to 30,000 times.
